article.title: Searching for axion stars and Q-balls with a terrestrial magnetometer network

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure estimates the parameter space probed by the Advanced GNOME for detecting ALP stars through their linear interaction with neutron spins. What is the significance of the solid green line?
choices: The solid green line represents the sensitivity limit of the current GNOME.
The solid green line represents the theoretical upper limit of the ALP mass.
The solid green line represents existing astrophysical constraints on the ALP-neutron coupling strength.
The solid green line represents the expected signal strength for an ALP star encounter with L = 10<sup>-3</sup> ly and v = 10<sup>-3</sup>c.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure explores the parameter space accessible to both the current GNOME and the Advanced GNOME for detecting ALP stars through their quadratic interaction. What key difference exists between the two instruments in terms of their sensitivity?
choices: The GNOME is sensitive to both electron and proton spin couplings, while the Advanced GNOME is only sensitive to neutron spin couplings.
The GNOME is only sensitive to ALP stars with masses above 10<sup>-14</sup> eV, while the Advanced GNOME is sensitive to masses down to 10<sup>-17</sup> eV.
The GNOME is limited by its bandwidth to ALP star encounter durations of less than 100 seconds, while the Advanced GNOME can detect encounters lasting up to 1000 seconds.
The GNOME is primarily sensitive to the spatial gradient of the ALP field, while the Advanced GNOME is primarily sensitive to the temporal oscillations of the field.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure displays the parameter space for ALP stars assuming a specific model for the ALP interaction potential U($). What is the key takeaway from the overlap of the grey and pink shaded regions?
choices: The overlap identifies the values of ALP mass and decay constant that are consistent with both frequent encounters with Earth and constraints from other observations.
The overlap highlights the parameter space where ALP stars are expected to form stable configurations based on this specific potential model.
The overlap demonstrates the range of ALP star radii and masses that are detectable by current and future magnetometer technology.
The overlap represents the region where the chosen ALP potential model accurately reflects the observed properties of dark matter.

multiple_choice_question.text: This equation estimates the energy shift experienced by atomic spins during a Q-star encounter due to the quadratic coupling of the ALP field. What is the significance of the factor  \'v/c\'?
choices: It accounts for the relativistic time dilation experienced by the atomic spins due to their motion relative to the Q-star.
It represents the ratio of the Q-star\'s escape velocity to the speed of light, highlighting the strength of the gravitational interaction.
It arises from the combination of the time-dependent nature of the ALP field and the non-zero relative velocity between Earth and the Q-star.
It reflects the suppression factor associated with the quadratic nature of the ALP-spin coupling compared to the linear coupling.
